awd_titl_txt: Testing and Estimation for Multi-Modality Single Cell Genomics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop new statistical analysis methodologies for data produced by a new technology known as single cell CRISPR screens, which promise to help unravel the molecular mechanisms of human disease and guide drug development. This technology discovers the functions of crucial but poorly understood genomic regions by knocking them out and then measuring the impact on the cell.  Given these possibilities, this technology has attracted enormous interest in both academia and industry, leading to its rapidly growing adoption. However, the statistical analysis of the data produced by CRISPR screens presents a major challenge to realizing their promise. The PI will tackle several of the most important statistical analysis challenges presented by this technology and implement the resulting methodologies in software tools. These tools will help scientists draw reliable conclusions from their single cell CRISPR screen data and therefore accelerate progress in the prognosis, diagnosis, and treatment of human disease. The project will provide training opportunities to graduate students by involving them in the research. 

The PI recently leveraged the distilled conditional randomization test (dCRT) methodology to design SCEPTRE, a computationally efficient, well-calibrated, and powerful analysis method for single cell CRISPR screens. In this project, the PI will expand his recent work on association testing for single cell CRISPR screens to more challenging problem settings (non-interventional screens) and more challenging inferential tasks (estimation and interaction detection). First, the PI will extend the ideas underlying SCEPTRE to address the problem of association testing in multi-omics screens, the observational counterparts of CRISPR screens. Second, the PI will develop a procedure to estimate the effect of knocking out a regulatory element on the expression of a gene based on single cell CRISPR screens. This will require more carefully accounting for the indirect measurement mechanism of CRISPR perturbations. Third, the PI will design a test of interaction between two regulatory elements, also based on CRISPR screens. This problem is even harder but critical to capturing the complexity of gene regulation. Finally, the resulting methods will be implemented in an integrated software package designed for practical application to real single cell data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The perturb-seq assay is a new experimental technique that introduces a large number of CRISPR-based genetic perturbations into a population of cells and then measures the consequences for gene activity at single-cell resolution. By dissecting the function of genetic variants implicated in human diseases, perturb-seq has the potential to revolutionize our understanding of their molecular origins. However, its analysis is fraught with statistical and computational challenges. The focus of this project was to develop statistical theory and methodology, as well as associated software, to tackle these challenges.

The project led to the development of statistical methodologies for three central problems in perturb-seq analysis: (1) determining which cells received which perturbations, (2) testing for association between perturbations and gene activity, and (3) estimating the impact of a perturbation on gene activity. While previous analysis methods tended to overstate the impact of perturbations on gene activity, the proposed methods were shown to be much more reliable, both theoretically and empirically. The theoretical portion of this work, published in the leading journal Annals of Statistics, advanced the understanding of the broader area of conditional independence testing.

The aforementioned methodological advances were implemented in a software package (sceptre), providing a complete pipeline for perturb-seq data analysis. This package is widely regarded as the state of the art among perturb-seq experimentalists, who appreciate its emphasis on user-friendliness, computational efficiency, and statistical rigor. sceptre has been incorporated as an analysis methodology into PerturBase, the largest existing database of perturb-seq datasets and analyses, containing 122 datasets, each of which was analyzed with the sceptre software. Furthermore, sceptre is recommended by 10x Genomics, the leading manufacturer of perturb-seq kits, to its users.

In the final part of the project, the PI collaborated with scientists to apply sceptre to interrogate the consequences of genetic variants implicated in blood traits (such as platelet counts), pediatric cancer, bone mineral density, and colorectal cancer. The paper on blood traits, a landmark work published in Science, was the first to use perturb-seq to systematically study the function of variants implicated in human traits by genome-wide association studies. The software has also had an impact beyond the PI's group, having successfully been employed to study autism spectrum disorder, breast cancer, autoimmune diseases, and fundamental biology.

The research supported by this project was disseminated to a wide range of scientists across statistics, biology, industry, and academia. It brought the research team in contact with perturb-seq experimentalists, through conferences as well as through the PI's participation in the Impact of Genomic Variation of Function consortium, which plans to use sceptre to analyze the perturb-seq data it produces. Finally, this project supported the PI's close mentorship of several master's and PhD students.

The outcomes of this project highlight the transformative potential of integrating robust statistical tools with experimental innovations, paving the way for a deeper understanding of how genetic factors shape health and disease.
